ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned how to code using python
I had never taken an S&DS class that worked in Python before, so I gained a good working knowledge of several important Python packages from this course
I learned to use some python for data analysis purposes.
Techniques for working with data, python
Python programming.
Not much tbh
Numpy, Pandas, Jupyter Notebooks, Github, Anaconda, Spark, and statistical analysis methods using these tools, such as Gradient Descent.
computational
gradient descent, dictionary learning, networks, etc.
I developed Python coding skills and surveyed a variety of topics in data science.
Basic knowledge of tools and packages in Python (numpy, pandas...etc)
I learned different data wrangling and analysis skills in Python through packages like NumPy and Pandas.
python
Machine Learning, Optimization, Python
I learned about some mathematical methods behind optimization techniques and how to use related Python packages
Learned about various ways one can approach data analysis with python, especially using python packages.
Absolutely nothing.
Proficiency with Python, spark, k means, stochastic gradient descent

This course provides a survey overview of a variety of topicsgradient descent, working with pandas, pytorch, spark, a little bit of natural language processing (bag of words, topic modeling, etc.). You really don't go into depth on some of the other things that are included. For example, the course had one lecture where we went over an example of deep learning, but if you don't have an existing background in it or do research outside of class, you're not going to get much out of that. I'm a little split on my feelings of how well I feel I've learned the topics of the course. Roy himself would say this is a survey class, so it's not the place to learn any of these topics in depth, but rather you should take more classes that go into greater depth. I'd argue that due to the number of pre-reqs this class has, many of the folks taking it are upperclassmen already... how much time does that leave for taking in-depth classes?
I learned to use Python and to use relevant libraries to do data analysis.
python coding
I learned generally about different functions in python
I got more practice with coding in python and using spark and ghc

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strength: pset based
weakness: lectures are not easily transferrable to homework

The problem sets are designed very well. They are very interesting and do a very good job challenging us to practice the concepts we've learned in class.

The course could be improved if it was more engaging. I loved the two classes where we split into groups and worked through a pandas exercise together. Everyone was very engaged, and I learned a lot from my classmates, which was awesome. In normal classes, I felt like many people were tuning out.
The strengths are that you learn to use python and some of its  packages. To be honest, lectures were pretty dry.
Assignments forced me to really engage with python and the material rather than sticking at a surface level understanding. Lectures often felt a bit slow.

Lectures not super engaging at times, and also sometimes difficult to make the connection between lectures and homework.

There were a few days where we did group work and learning in pandas instead of the normal lecture format, and the course was at its best during those days in my opinion! Especially since the homework that followed was so closely related to the class work

One of the TFs also made a "coding best practices" document after the first programming assignment was graded, and it was super useful! Might want to just post it on the class server before the first homework is even assigned in future classes!

Strength: a lot of knowledge
Weakness: bad teaching

Strength: teaches a lot of practical stuff
Weakness: the lectures are a bit dull. It's just the prof reading off his codes
The course is well organized but that's about it. Lectures are extremely boring, homework are unnecessarily hard and the content is easy to disengage from.
Lectures at times could be a bit dry

I was not a fan of the lectures- they were rather dry and difficult to stay engaged with. Additionally, the lack of a clear course layout and deadlines was frustrating, as homework deadlines were constantly moved around and it felt like a lot of them were backloaded which made the end of the semester rather stressful. I also felt like the expectations for the homeworks weren't very clear, especially for the final extra credit assignment where we weren't really given any direction. Lastly, the lack of effort to upload or live stream lectures was very frustrating, given the fact that we are in a pandemic and the instructor was not willing to be understanding.
I thought the problem sets were interesting, and useful in understanding Python syntax and data structures. Additionally, the in class work was useful. I also thought the ed discussion was helpful, as well as the student collaboration.
good

Strength: introduces to multiple topics in ML, great survey course
Weakness: no weakness
The problem sets are enjoyable but could be different from what was taught in class. Office hours are great for these problem sets.

The only strength was that there were no exams. However, given the unorganized nature of the course, having a test would have been impossible. The material was not presented in a good manner, the structure was horrible, the assignments were worthless, and I learned nothing.

Strengths: very comprehensive overview 
Weaknesses: this class, especially during lectures, can be insufferably boring if youre already experienced in Python
weakness- could provide better study resources

It's nice to get a chance to use Python in an S&DS course. Most of the S&DS courses I've taken use R. Really liked getting the chance to learn how to use GitHub--really hope that is kept in future iterations of the course! However, as the course is currently organized, I don't think students are able to get the most out of the material and tools we work with (which are genuinely very interesting/useful!). I think code in the lecture notes could be commented better and headers made more clear (especially as this is an expectation for us when turning in our assignments--I don't think the lecture code provides a good example of this!). For example, there would be a code block that purposefully didn't run in order to demonstrate a common mistake or error. However, instead of an explanation in the code comments or markdown text around the code, there was typically only an "oops" written. Yeah... not particularly illuminating. One could argue we should take notes during class on this (and I did when the code was run/explained in class), but Roy often leaves large sections of the lecture notes for us to run and understand on our own. Comments would be super appreciated for clarity and learning here!!!! The latex documents with the more theory-centric lectures were much better organized and explained than the jupyter notebook files. Roy is a very kind professor and seems invested in student learning, but I unfortunately didn't really click with his lecture style. It wasn't the Jupyter notebooks per se, more just his way of explaining things.

The TF Daniel was great. One of the peer tutors (shout-out to Sam) was also really helpful in office hours and clearly knew the material and the math behind it, and could answer questions in a detailed manner. I didn't feel the same way about the other ULA's, who essentially worked exclusively off their homework solutions from the previous years.
The course could be made so that the psets teach you rather than test you.
be more specific and go details about each topic

A real strength of the course is the individuality - you can really figure out the psets by yourself and learn in a trial by error way, which I personally liked a lot. There are also a lot of opportunities to ask questions via GitHub and Ed. A weakness would be that the lectures can be a bit dry. It is also tough to really understand the participation component of the grade because it seems difficult to fulfill and encourages students to ask random questions that they don't actually need answered.

Lectures felt pretty ineffective in this course. There were a lot of typos and mistakes and it felt kind of arbitrary and disorganized. It didn't really feel like prof Lederman was very engaged in the course. The homeworks were the same way. The course had a lot of potential in terms of useful stats skills but was disappointing because it was disorganized and not engaging at all
It was quite terribly organized. Homework assignments do not seem clearly written and some have many mistakes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: a good s&ds elective, but a lot of self-learning needed

To be honest, I took this course because I was looking to learn some data analysis and it was the only course that fit into my schedule, and I did not learn as much data analysis as I had hoped, although it was a useful introduction to python and some packages ini it.

If you don't know python and want to get a survey of many topics in data science, this course felt like a reasonable way to do so. It will likely feel slow to those who have some knowledge in either area.
No. The course content and the assignment weren't organized well.
Nope, unless you need it. Hard to understand the lectures
Maybe if you're taking it with friends, but I think this would be a tough course to take alone with no support from fellow students!

No.
Bad teaching. Cannot understand the course.
Yes if you want to learn more about data science (especially if you want to be a data analyst in the future).
Only if it fulfills major requirements.
If someone is looking for a relatively relaxed course for a S&DS credit.
If you really want to learn python, it probably is a good class. Otherwise, I would recommend other programming courses with better instructors.
yes
Yes!

DEFINITELY NOT! I rarely have a very strong opinion on a course, but this one was different. This was BY FAR the worst course I have ever taken. I learned absolutely nothing and the structure was horrible. The work was not hard, but it was useless. There were so many typos and mistakes to the point that the material and assignments became confusing (also little effort to fix this). The lectures were so unengaging and not helpful that there was no use in going, but I still went because there was a "participation" portion of the grade of this lecture. This course is not required for anything, so absolutely no one should take it. Seriously, if you are reading this, please do not take this course. I cannot go back in time and change my decision to take the course, but do not make the same mistake as me. There are plenty of better and more useful S&DS courses to take. Do not take this because you think it will be easy. While it was not challenging, it was a complete waste of time. You will regret it.

This is a good overview of data science in Python even though the lectures are not entertaining at all. Since this is a major requirement I suppose my opinion doesnt matter as students will inevitably take it.
yes, for those who have interest in statistics

I think it really depends. I took this course to fulfill a major elective. It's a good opportunity to get exposure to Python, GitHub and some of the tools commonly used in it. Roy is a really kind person and in my opinion, does genuinely care about student learning. Roy bills this as a survey course, an introduction to the topics that doesn't go in-depth. He recommends you take further classes in the topics to truly learn them. There are a lot of pre-reqs though... to the point that many people in the course are upperclassmen and only have so much time to actually do that. Keep that in mind when managing expectations for what you'd get out of this course. I didn't think lectures were very well-organized or engaging. Personally, I spent a lot of time on homework assignments, which was where a lot of the learning happened for me.
Yes, I think this course helps a lot in learning Python and using it for relevant Data Analysis work.
I would recommend this course to a student who is really interested in a more self-directed kind of class.

I would not. Prof Lederman didn't really seem to care about the course. The material was pretty disorganized. It seemed like he structured the work around doing the least amount of grading and organizing possible. He also gave little to no feedback throughout

extras.title: AMTH 262 01/CPSC 262 01/S&DS 262 01/S&DS 562 01 - Comp Tools for Data Science
